speaker: Paul Noble
text: So, enough about the history of the French language. Let's get started.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: Sounds a bit like the English letter J pronounced in a French way. So again?

text: The word for "visited" in French, "visited" is?

speaker: Paul Noble
text: So again, the word for "I have" is?

speaker: Paul Noble
text: So how would you say, "I have visited"?

speaker: Paul Noble
text: The, The Louvre. The Louvre Art Gallery in French is of course?

speaker: Paul Noble
text: So how would you say, "I have visited The Louvre"?

speaker: Paul Noble
text: So how would you say, "I have visited the park"?

speaker: Paul Noble
text: Now again, don't worry at this point about trying to remember what it is we've done already. First thing students will, will often do when I'm teaching them is they'll panic and think, "Oh my goodness, I'm going to forget what it is you're teaching me. I- are we already moving on to something new?" But that is exactly what I want. I want you to forget it because I'm going to remind you of it in a few minutes. And if you haven't forgot it, it's hard to remind you.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: How do you think you'd say, "You have visited the park"?

speaker: Paul Noble
text: "Have you" in French, so to turn "you have" into a question, you simply, you change round the word order just like you do in English. In English you have, "you have," which in French is?

speaker: Paul Noble
text: And to ask a question in English, we simply change the "you have" round and say, "Have you?" Which in French becomes?

speaker: Paul Noble
text: So how would you say, "Have you visited the park?"

speaker: Paul Noble
text: What about, "Have you visited The Louvre?"

speaker: Paul Noble
text: The word for "prepared" in French is?

speaker: Paul Noble
text: How would you say, "I have prepared"?

speaker: Paul Noble
text: How would you say, "I have prepared the coffee"?

speaker: Paul Noble
text: Again, don't worry too much about trying to remember all this. I'll be introducing a lot of concepts earlier on, in order to give you a chance to forget them, so that I can remind you of them later. And as we go through this process of you having the words introduced to you, forgetting them, and then being reminded of them again, you'll find that they just start to stick without any effort at trying to remember them or trying to memorize them. They will just stick eventually.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: To say "for you" in French, "for you" in French is?

speaker: Paul Noble
text: So how would you say, "I have prepared the coffee for you?"

speaker: Marion
text: J'ai préparé le café pour vous.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: "The roast beef" in French, "the roast beef" is?

speaker: Paul Noble
text: So it sort of sounds like, it sounds a bit like the English, but pronounced in a very French way.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: So, how would you say, "I have prepared the roast beef"?

speaker: Paul Noble
text: To say "for dinner" in French, you'll say literally, "For the dinner." The French always say "for the dinner," rather than "for dinner" which in French is?

speaker: Paul Noble
text: So how would you say, "I have prepared roast beef for dinner," or as the French would say, "I have prepared the roast beef for the dinner"?

speaker: Marion
text: J'ai préparé le rosbif pour le dîner.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: Now, it's important to make sure when you're pronouncing "dinner" in French to pronounce it as-

speaker: Paul Noble
text: ... sort of has an 'ay' sound on the end because it's such a similar word to the English. Um, students, people will frequently pronounce it, English speakers will pronounce it as "dinner" or something like that. But it is correctly said as?

speaker: Paul Noble
text: Yep. So it's got that 'ay' sound at the end.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: So again, how would you say, "I have prepared the roast beef for the dinner?"

speaker: Marion
text: J'ai préparé le rosbif pour le dîner.
